result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

10:37 AM Defendant Stefanie A Hoevelkamp in court.  Attorney Joseph R Kennedy in court for Stefanie A Hoevelkamp.  Prosecuting attorney Abbey Nickolie in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Case called for Plea hearing.
Parties discuss Count 1.  Defense agrees to having Count 1 dismissed and read in.
Court conducts plea colloquy. 
Attorney Pitzo in court at 11:04 and advises Count 1 should be dismissed and read in.
Attorney Pitzo excused.
Court continues plea colloquy.  Defendant enters a guilty but not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect plea to Count 2.  Court finds defendant not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect.  Count 1 is dismissed and read in.
Court orders the defendant committed to the Department of Health Services for a length to be determined.
This commitment commences on 10/5/22.
Days of credit to be determined.
Court orders a conditional release plan to be prepared adn filed with the court within 21 days.

Defendant to comply with I.D. Processing.  If DNA sample has not been taken from the defendant, the Court orders sample to be taken;  and it may be expunged under 165.77(4) Wis. Statutes. Defendant is not to share, reproduce or distribute any personal and/or identifying information about the crime victim(s), except to their attorney.
